Graphical abstract In this work, Ti3C2Ti x MXene is modified by CTAB and FOTS to increase the hydrophobicity of MXenes. The ammonia production rate and faradaic efficiency are improved after surface modification. Hydrophobic treatment of the catalyst surfaces can suppress the competitive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) during the nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR). In this work, the surface of Ti3C2Ti x MXene is modified by cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) and trimethoxy (3,3,4,4,5,5,6,6,7,7,8,8,8-tridecafluorooctyl) silane (FOTS) to increase the hydrophobicity of MXenes. The ammonia (NH3) production rate and faradaic efficiency (FE) are improved from 37.62 to 54.01 μg h−1 mg−1 cat. and 5.5% to 18.1% at −0.7 V vs. RHE, respectively after surface modification. 15N isotopic labeling experiment confirms that nitrogen in produced ammonia originates from N2 in the electrolyte. The excellent NRR activity of surface hydrophobic MXenes is mainly due to surfactant molecules, which inhibit the entry of water molecules and the competitive HER, which have been verified by in situ FT-IR, DFT and molecular dynamics calculations. This strategy provides an ingenious method to design more active NRR electrocatalysts. Keywords Electrocatalysis Nitrogen reduction reaction Surface hydrophobic modification MXene Ti3C2Ti x 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3) is one of the most widely applied chemicals in the world, used in biology, chemistry, medicine and other fields as the main nitrogen source when synthesizing fibers, fertilizers and explosives. Recently, using nitrogen (N2) to synthesize NH3 has aroused great attention [1–3]. However, N2 as a chemically inert gas, with N≡N triple bond and relatively high bond energy, is difficult to be reduced [4,5]. Since the 20th century, Haber-Bosch’s process of synthesizing NH3 under high temperature (300–500 °C) and high pressure (200–300 atm) are often used in industry [6]. However, high energy consumption and harmful gas emissions in Haber-Bosch’s process have largely limited the development of this nitrogen fixation technology [7,8]. Thus, new nitrogen fixation methods that meet the conditions of sustainable development are in urgent need. Nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) is gradually studied for reducing N2 to NH3 under mild conditions [9,10]. NRR has great potential due to the use of renewable energy, such as the conversion of water and wind power into electricity and H2O as the hydrogen source [11,12], in response to sustainable development policies. Besides, electroreduction of N2 provides a sustainable way with great fit in an electrified industry, which not only stores intermittent electrical energy into useful chemicals but also directly offsets global CO2 emissions emitted by the conventional Haber-Bosch process [13–16]. However, the lack of catalysts with high activity and selectivity need to be urgently solved in NRR [17]. So far, researchers have conducted a series of studies on precious metal catalysts (Au [18] and Ru [19]), which have shown excellent activity in the NRR process. However, the high cost is destined to limit their development. The 2D/2D heterojunction formed by combining various 2D nanosheets (such as MoS2 and MXene) exhibits a large interface contact area and strong interface interaction due to the close face-to-face contact between two different 2D materials, which can effectively enhance electron transfer ability and has been proven outstanding NRR performance [20,21]. The low cost and simple synthesis method make them become the most popular type of NRR catalysts at present. MXene is an inorganic 2D compound with a large number of functional groups on the surface [22], such as hydroxyl (–OH) and oxy (-O) [23], which is composed of layered transition metal carbides or nitrides and prepared by selective etching of the intermediate layer. MXene has been widely used in various fields including catalysis [24], supercapacitors [25], gas sensors [26], and water purification [27], due to the excellent electrical conductivity, easily adjustable hydrophilic type and more active sites [28], which are beneficial for electrocatalysis. As is well known, 2D nanosheets are prone to self-stacking, especially during electrocatalytic processes. Therefore, the mass transfer of reactants/products is easily affected, resulting in poor electrocatalytic performance of the catalyst. However, many complex nanosheets obtained by surface modification and other methods prevent self-stacking, and porous nanosheets expose more active sites. Besides, the poor oxidation resistance and hydration resistance of MXene are obvious disadvantages for the storage and catalytic process [29]. MXene is extremely easy to be oxidized and degraded under environmental conditions, which is mainly due to the large amount of –OH and -O on its surface [30]. –OH and -O make Ti3C2 MXene surface hydrophilic, which has more H active sites and contributes to hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) but not NRR [31]. Chen et al. proposed a surface engineering method (SAM), which introduced new functional groups instead of –OH and -O to achieve hydrophobic treatment and applied it to gas sensors [32]. Inspired by this study, we propose a new strategy of surface hydrophobic modification using surfactants to hydrophobically modify the surface of MXene. Meanwhile, the surface chemical functionalization of electrocatalysts can modify the electrode/electrolyte interface structure, thereby improving electrocatalytic activity and selectivity [33–35]. Herein, Ti3C2 MXene is successfully synthesized and modified by different surfactants. In a 0.1 M HCl electrolyte, the surface hydrophobic modified Ti3C2 MXene achieves a high NH3 production rate of 54.01 μg h−1 mg−1 cat. and high faradaic efficiency (FE) of 18.1% at −0.7 V vs. RHE. Besides, the surface hydrophobic modified Ti3C2 MXene shows excellent selectivity and durability during the NRR process. Most importantly, Ti3C2 MXene via surface hydrophobic modification maintains excellent electrochemical performance even after long-time storage. 15N isotopic labeling experiment confirms that nitrogen in produced ammonia originates from N2 in the electrolyte. In situ FT-IR, DFT and molecular dynamics calculations confirm that the excellent NRR activity of surface hydrophobic MXenes is mainly due to surfactant molecules, which inhibits the entry of water molecules and the competitive HER. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Ti3C2 MXene Ti3AlC2 powder (98%, 400 mesh) was used as raw material. Firstly, Ti3AlC2 powder (3 g) was put into the 40% HF solution (360 mL) and stirred at room temperature for 72 h to obtain Ti3C2. The mixed solution was centrifuged at 6000 r min−1 for 3–5 min, and washed with millet water repeatedly until the pH was 6–7. Then it was dried in a vacuum oven at 70 °C and for 12 h. After grinding, it was collected in a centrifuge tube for subsequent experiments. 2.2 Synthesis of Ti3C2 MXene modified by cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) (CT-MX) CTAB powder was used as raw material. Firstly, CTAB (3 g) was scattered in deionized water (50 mL) and kept stirring for 30 min to ensure uniform mixing. MXene Ti3C2 (0.25 g) was dispersed in the solution and kept stirring at 40 °C for 24 h collected by suction filtration and dried in a vacuum oven at 70 °C for 24 h. Finally, CT-MX was put into a centrifuge tube after grinding. 2.3 Synthesis of Ti3C2 MXene modified by trimethoxy (3,3,4,4,5,5,6,6,7,7,8,8,8-tridecafluorooctyl) silane (FOTS) (FO-MX) FOTS was used as raw material. Firstly, FOTS (2 mg) was dispersed in ethanol (50 mL), and MXene (400 mg) was put into the solution and stirred for 24 h at room temperature to make it uniform. To remove impurities, the mixed solution was repeatedly washed and filtered with deionized water and ethanol, and the collected solids were dried in a vacuum oven at 70 °C for 24 h and placed in a centrifuge tube. 2.4 Characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis test was performed at Rigaku Ultima IV of Rigaku Corporation (Japan) to characterize the phase of the material, Cu K α radiation source worked at 40 kV, and the parameter λ was set as 1.5418 Å. The X-ray photoelectron spectrometry (XPS) analysis test was performed on Thermo ESCALAB 250XI (USA), the Al-K α radiation voltage was set as 1486.6 eV, and 284.8 eV of C 1s binding energy was used to process the data. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) analysis tests were tested on FEI Nova Nano SEM 450 (USA). The transmission electron microscope (TEM) and the high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) were measured on a JEOL JEM2100F transmission electron microscope (Japan) and the acceleration voltage was set as 200 kV. The absorbance data were examined on the UV-2600i ultraviolet–visible spectrophotometer of SHIMADZU (Japan). 2.5 Electrochemical measurements The electrochemical test was performed on the CHI660 electrochemical workstation (Shanghai Chenhua, China) with a three-electrode configuration, modified MXene was used as the working electrode, Ag/AgCl with saturated KCl was the reference electrode, and the graphite rod was the counter electrode. The preparation method of the working electrode was as follows. Firstly, 5 mg of catalyst was dispersed in 490 μL of absolute ethanol and 490 μL of deionized water. Then, 20 μL of Nafion solution (5 wt.%) was added to the mixture, followed by sonicating for 30 min. Finally, 10 μL ink was coated on a 3 mm diameter pre-polished glassy carbon electrode to achieve a load mass of 0.7 mg cm−2 and dried in an oven. The purity of N2 and Ar was 99.999% in the experiment. The Nafion membrane was first boiled in water at 80 °C for 1 h, next in H2O2 and water at 80 °C for an hour, respectively, then 0.5 M H2SO4 for 3 h, and finally in water for 6 h before nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) test. The potentials were converted to RHE by the following formula: E (vs. RHE) = E (vs. Ag/AgCl) + 0.197 + 0.0591 × pH. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) testing was examined at ambient temperature with a scan rate of 5 mV s−1. The electrolyte used in the electrochemical test was 0.1 M HCl which was blown with nitrogen for 30 min (PH = 1). During the experiment, N2 was firstly fed into 0.05 M H2SO4 and 0.1 M KOH to remove impurities, and then ventilated into a double-chamber electrolytic cell sustainably at a rate of 20 mL min−1. 2.6 Determination of NH3 In the experiment, the concentration of NH3 was identified by indoxyl blue spectrophotometry. The specific method is as follows. Firstly, 2 mL of the solution was taken out of the cathode compartment, and then 2 mL of 1.0 M NaOH solution containing 5 wt.% salicylic acid and 5 wt.% sodium citrate, 1 mL 0.05 M NaClO and 0.2 mL 1 wt.% Na2[Fe (NO)(CN)5] ·2H2O was added to the electrolyte in turn and mixed uniformly. The absorption spectrum was tested on a UV-2600i UV-Vis spectrophotometer after 2 h. The absorbance value at 655 nm wavelength was recorded. A series of gradient concentration NH4Cl solution calibration standard curves are presented. The standard curve (y = 0.4927x + 0.09076, R 2 = 0.999) was fitted to show a good linear relationship between concentration and absorbance. NH3 yield rate was obtained by the following formula. (1) N H 3 y i e l d r a t e = c ∗ 0.318 ∗ V / ( t ∗ m ) Where c is the concentration of NH4Cl obtained from the standard curve; V is the electrolyte volume in the experiment; t is the time set in the experiment; m is the content of the catalyst smeared on the working electrode. The FE was obtained by the following formula. (2) F E = 3 ∗ F ∗ c ∗ 0.318 ∗ V / ( 17 ∗ Q ) where 3 is the number of electrons transferred to produce an NH3 molecule; F is the Faraday constant, Q is the number of charges generated during the experiment. 2.7 Determination of N2H4 The N2H4 content was calculated by the method proposed by Watt and Chrisp. p-C9H11NO (5.99 g), concentrated hydrochloric acid (30 mL) and C2H5OH (300 mL) were used as the raw materials of the color reagent. The specific method is as follows, after the experiment, 5 mL of electrolyte was taken out from the cathode chamber and added to the 5 mL of color reagent. After 10 min, the absorption spectrum at 455 nm was obtained by the UV-2600i ultraviolet–visible spectrophotometer. A series of gradient concentration N2H4 solution calibration standard curves are presented. The standard curve (y = 1.715x + 0.0035, R 2 = 0.998) was fitted to show a good linear relationship between concentration and absorbance. 2.8 Electrochemical in-situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) test All tests are performed at 0.1 M HCl saturated with N2. The instrument is a Nexus 870 spectrometer (Nicolet) equipped with a liquid nitrogen-cooled MCT-A detector. CaF2 is used to test the IR window. Before the test, the electrode is pushed to the window to access the IR battery with thin layer configuration, which is between the electrode and the IR window. In situ FTIR spectra are collected using a time-resolved FTIR spectroscopy program. Eq. (3) is used to calculate the relative change in reflectivity. (3) Δ R R = R ( E s ) - R ( E R ) R ( E R ) In the above formula, R(E S) and R(E R) are the accumulated spectra collected at sample potential E S and reference potential E R, respectively. Each cumulative spectrum consisting of 200 single-beam spectra was collected and encoded with a resolution of 4 cm−1. 2.9 DFT calculation details The first principle calculations of the mechanism of NRR are revealed by the Vienna ab initio simulation package. The projected enhancement wave pseudopotential and the generalized gradient approximation of Perdew, Burke and Enzzerhof (PBE) exchange–correlation functional are in the program to optimize the structure. The cutoff energy of the plane waves basis is set to 500 eV and the Monkhorst-Pack mesh for K-sampling in the adsorption energy calculation is 3 × 3 × 1. In addition, it is considered that van der Waals interactions are corrected by DFT-D2. The electronic self-consistent iteration is set to 10−5 eV, and the positions of all of the atoms are completely relaxed until the residual force on each atom is below 0.02 eV Å −1. A vacuum layer of 15 Å along the z-direction is applied to avoid periodic interactions. MD simulations were calculated by the large-scale atomic/molecular massively parallel simulator (LAMMPS) software. The dimension of the simulation box is 3.48 nm × 1.90 nm × 13.90 nm, and the models consist of 162 Ti atoms, 108C atoms, 9 Br atoms and 9 CTAB molecules. The N (nitrogen molecules)/N (water molecules) are set to 40/2000. Canonical ensemble (NVT) simulations were performed at a constant temperature (300 K) using a Nose-Hoover thermostat for 1 ns with a time step of 1 fs. And the substrate (Ti, C, Br) was fixed in the MD simulation. The added modified group has a certain charge and is in a state of free movement. The Lennard-Jones equation was used to calculate the interaction between Ti, C, Br and CTAB molecules, nitrogen and water molecules. The expression is as follows. (4) U L J = ε ij r m r ij 12 - 2 r m r ij 6 + q i q j r ij In the above formula, εij represents the depth of the potential energy well in kcal mol−1; rm is the distance between the two particles when the potential energy is the smallest. rij is the distance between two ions; qi and qj are the charges of particles i and j, respectively. The Dreiding force field was used for CTAB and Nitrogen molecules. Meanwhile, the water molecules were represented by the TIP3P model, which is compatible with the Dreiding force field. The interaction between gas molecules and substrate included both van der Waals and electrostatic terms. The parameters for the van der Waals interactions between gas and substrate were calculated from their parameters using the Lorentz-Berthelot mixing rules, where σij = (σii + σjj )/2, and εij = (εii × εjj )1/2. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst synthesis, morphologies and structures The preparation process of surface-modified Ti3C2 MXene is shown in Fig. 1 (a). Firstly, Ti3C2 MXene is obtained by selectively etching the Al layer in Ti3AlC2 using an HF solution [36], generating a large amount of oxygen (-O) and hydroxyl (–OH) functional groups on its surface [30,37–39]. Subsequently, MXene is modified by two kinds of surfactants (cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) and trimethoxy (3,3,4,4,5,5,6,6,7,7,8,8,8-tridecafluorooctyl) silane (FOTS)). The resulting materials are noted as CT-MX and FO-MX, respectively. CTAB are cationic surfactants with a long-chain structure consisting of positively charged hydrophilic heads and neutral hydrophobic tails [40]. As mentioned earlier, MXene has a large amount of –OH and -O, which are ionized generating a negative potential in the solution [30]. The positively charged hydrophilic head of the surfactant can strongly interact with these polar functional groups, so that the orientation of the surfactant molecules is rearranged, and the hydrophobic tail is exposed (Fig. 1b), making the surface of the material hydrophobic [41]. While FOTS molecules were deposited onto the surface of MXene using self-assembly monolayer (SAM) technology. As a silane molecule, FOTS has hydrophobic functional groups, so the modified FO-MX also has hydrophobicity [42]. The adsorption of surfactants requires electrostatic interaction and occupies the dedicated active site for the H bond [43], which can inhibit HER and improve the efficiency of NH3 production. Fig. 2 (a) presents the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the three materials. After surface modification, the (002) peak of Ti3C2 MXene shifts to a lower angle, indicating that hydrophobic modification can increase the interplanar spacing [32], which is beneficial for the entry of N2 during the NRR process, making the reaction more rapid and enough. At the same time, the (004), (006) and (104) peaks of Ti3C2 MXene at 18.2°, 27.8° and 36.7° are attenuated by the surface hydrophobic modification [44,45]. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) was used to investigate the change in flake thickness before and after hydrophobic modification (Fig. S1a and Fig. 2b). For easier detection, Ti3C2 MXene and CT-MX were added to deionized water and sonicated for 20 min to obtain monolayer nanosheets. Fig. S1(a) and Fig. 2(b) show the thin layers of Ti3C2 MXene and CT-MX after sonication, respectively. It can be found that under the same time by sonicated, CT-MX has a larger dispersed sheet, with a lateral dimension of about 1 μm, which is about twice that of Ti3C2 MXene. This phenomenon may be due to the difficulty in dispersing CT-MX in water after hydrophobic modification. AFM analysis shows that the thickness of Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets is about 2.2 nm (Fig. S1b), while the CT-MX nanosheets have an average thickness of 4.9 nm (Fig. 2c), which proves that CTAB molecules are successfully attached to the Ti3C2 MXene surface, resulting in the increase in the thickness. The scanning electron microscope (SEM) images of Ti3AlC2, Ti3C2 MXene and CT-MX are shown in Fig. 2(d–f). Ti3AlC2 presents a block structure (Fig. 2d). After being selectively etched by HF, a multilayer material similar to an accordion structure is obtained (Fig. 2e). After surface hydrophobic treatment, the multilayer structure becomes looser (Fig. 2f), which is conducive to exposing more active sites. As shown in Fig. S2, the TEM image can clearly illustrate the structure of CT-MX with a clean surface, obvious edges [46], as well as the multi-layered nanosheet structure according to the shade. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) is used to demonstrate the successful synthesis of CT-MX materials. As shown in Fig. S3, four obvious peaks appear in the curve of CTAB. The peaks at 756 and 987 cm−1 are assigned to the internal and external symmetric stretch. The peak at 1458 cm−1 corresponds to the association of hydroxy acid salt and adsorbate F ion. The peak at 2900 cm−1 relates to the tensile vibration of the CH2 group [47]. Meanwhile, the curve of CT-MX appears two peaks at 700 and 1400 cm−1, which basically match the curve of CTAB respectively. In addition, CT-MX was analyzed by high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping (Fig. 2g). The element spectrum of EDS demonstrates the uniform distribution of Ti, C, and Br elements. At the same time, the uniform distribution of Br can also prove that the surface of Ti3C2 MXene is successfully modified by the surfactant CTAB. The contact angle was measured (Fig. 3 ) to prove that the surface hydrophobization treatment can effectively change the wettability of the material. The contact angle of Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets is only 9.27° at room temperature due to a large amount of –OH and –O groups on its surface [48], making it a super-hydrophilic material. After surface hydrophobic modification by FOTS and CTAB, the contact angles of FO-MX and CT-MX are increased to 116.7° and 127.9°, respectively, which are very close to super-hydrophobicity (θ > 150°) [32]. This indicates that FOTS and CTAB molecules interact with hydroxyl groups on the surface of MXene and effectively reduce the surface energy. This result confirms that hydrophobic modification can increase the water contact angle of the catalyst, which means it can enhance hydrophobicity. To distinguish the oxidation state and chemical composition of the elements in the CT-MX, XPS measurements are performed (Fig. 4 ). The survey spectrum of CT-MX shown in Fig. 4(a) indicates that the material contains C, Ti, O, F, and Br elements, CT-MX has a clear peak at 50.0°, corresponding to Br 3d, which is not present in MXene. This proves that the surface of Ti3C2 MXene is successfully modified by CTAB. The F signals are caused by the HF residues [49]. For the C 1s spectrum (Fig. 4b), there are three obvious peaks located at ∼286.3, ∼284.8, and ∼281.2 eV, which belong to COO, C–C, and C–Ti–O x bonds, respectively [50–52]. After analyzing the O 1s spectrum (Fig. 4c), two peaks are found at ∼531.5 and ∼529.8 eV, corresponding to the C–Ti–O x and Ti–O bonds, respectively [50]. For the Ti 2p spectrum (Fig. 4d), four double peaks of Ti 2p 1/2 and Ti 2p 3/2 with an area ratio of 1:2 are found [53]. Two peaks at ∼454.3 (Ti 2p 3/2) and ∼460.2 eV (Ti 2p 1/2) belong to the Ti–C bond. Another two peaks at ∼458.7 (Ti 2p 3/2) and ∼464.5 eV (Ti 2p 1/2) are ascribed to the Ti–O bond. The occurrence of TiO2 peaks can be attributed to the inevitable partial oxidation of MXene during the synthesis process [54]. The remaining peaks at ∼457.7/∼464.3 eV and ∼455.3/∼461.4 eV belong to Ti3+ and Ti2+, respectively, which is consistent with the previous XPS research reported on MXene materials [37,51,55,56]. After XPS analysis, CT-MX still maintains the original element valence after being hydrophobically modified, which proves that the surface hydrophobic layer is obtained after the surfactant treatment. 3.2 Electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction The electrocatalytic NRR experiment is carried out in an H-type dual-chamber cell, the electrolyte in the experiment was 0.1 M HCl. To ensure the accuracy of the experiment, the cell is checked for airtightness and an acid trap is installed at the other outlet of the electrolytic cell before the experiment to prevent the escape of NH3. During the reaction, H+ from dilute hydrochloric acid and N2 adsorbed on the surface of CT-MX to NH3 under the catalytic action. The indophenol blue method is used to detect the generated NH3, and the hydrazine is measured by the Watt and Crisp methods [57]. The absorbance concentration of NH4 + standard solution curve is demonstrated in Fig. S4. First, to determine the best potential of CT-MX, an LSV curve test is carried out (Fig. 5 a). The current density in the N2 and Ar saturated solutions gradually increases with the negative potential, which proves that the catalyst possesses NRR activity. The LSV curves of CT-MX, FO-MX and MXene in N2-saturated 0.1 M HCl were compared (Fig. S5a). It can be seen that FO-MX and CT-MX have higher current densities than MXene at the same potential. To determine the reason for the change in current density, the LSV curves of the three catalysts were tested in 0.1 M HCl without nitrogen filling (Fig. S5b). It was found that contrary to the previous case, MXene instead had a higher current density, indicating that the change in current density in 0.1 M HCl was caused by NRR, which proved that the hydrophobic modification was beneficial to enhance the NRR performance of the catalysts. Therefore, the potentials from −0.6 to −0.8 V vs. RHE are selected for the next systematic test. The NRR performance of CT-MX is tested at different potentials for 2 h, and the UV-visible absorption spectra are tested using the indoxyl blue method. The results are shown in Fig. 5(b), proving that CT-MX in the NRR process produces the most NH4 + and catalytic activity reaches the maximum at −0.7 V vs. RHE. The average NH3 production rate and the corresponding FE are calculated and shown in Fig. 5(c). As the potential becomes more negative, the NH3 production rate and FE of CT-MX gradually increase, reaching the maximum at −0.7 V vs. RHE (NH3 production rate: 54.01 μg h−1 mg−1 cat., FE: 18.1%). To determine the accuracy of the experiment, the electrocatalytic property of CT-MX sample at −0.9 V vs. RHE was tested (Fig. S6). CT-MX shows an NH3 yield rate of 31.31 μg h−1 mg−1 cat. at −0.9 V vs. RHE, which is lower than that tested at −0.7 V vs. RHE. This result confirms the optimal NRR behavior at −0.7 V vs. RHE. Compared with the previous work with different treatment methods [52–59], both the NH3 production rate and FE on MXene of our catalysts are much higher (Table S1). When the potential is lower than −0.7 V vs. RHE, the NH3 production rate and FE are drastically reduced. When the potential is more negative, the dominance of HER makes more H ions occupy the active sites, which hinders the adsorption of N atoms [58], resulting in a decrease in efficiency. Many studies have found that hydrophobic modification can inhibit the entry of water molecules to suppress HER, thereby improving NRR performance [59–61]. To verify the effect of hydrophobic modification on the electrocatalytic nitrogen fixation performance, three catalysts with different water contact angles were tested at the same potential, and the results are shown in Fig. 5(d). The maximum NH3 production rate and FE of Ti3C2 MXene are 37.62 μg h−1 mg−1 cat. and 5.5%. The NH3 production rates increase to 54.01 and 48.1 μg h−1 mg−1 cat., while FEs rise to 18.1% and 6.6% at −0.7 V vs. RHE for CT-MX and FO-MX, respectively. The results show that the nitrogen fixation performance is positively proportional to the degree of hydrophobicity. As the water contact angle increases, the nitrogen fixation performance correspondingly improves, which proves the successful implementation of our strategy. Through hydrophobic modification, the catalyst surface has a hydrophobic layer, which is beneficial for suppressing HER during the NRR process and improving the performance of NRR. Previous studies have shown that after hydrophobic modification, molecules are inserted between the MXene layers to increase the specific surface area [32], the results of BET specific surface area confirm this claim (Fig. S7). The specific surface area of MXene nanosheets is 2.407 m2 g−1, while the specific surface area of CT-MX after hydrophobic modification increases to 8.409 m2 g−1, so it can be concluded that the increase in the interlayer spacing can increase the specific surface area of the MXene and provide more active sites [32]. In addition, CTAB and FOTS can provide more interfacial activity [45], thereby improving the efficiency of NRR. After the experiment, no NH3 gas was detected in the linear acid trap. Meanwhile, the result of the content of the hydrazine hydrate test proves that no hydrazine hydrate is produced during the experiment, which illustrates that CT-MX material has excellent selectivity in NRR (Fig. S8). Before NRR, the UV-Vis spectrophotometer test is performed on the electrolyte with aeration for 30 min, and the result shows that only a little NH3 is discovered, which rules out the influence of a small amount of NH3 in the cylinder and air on the experimental results (Fig. S9). To verify the long-term stability of the CT-MX material at the optimal potential, the durability test is carried out at −0.7 V vs. RHE. The result reveals that the current density remains stable after 12 h of continuous NRR and the NH3 production rate and FE are not significantly reduced after 5 cycles test (Fig. 6 a and Fig. S10), indicating that the hydrophobically modified Ti3C2 MXene possesses good durability. To avoid the influence of the flow rate of N2 on the experimental results, NRR with different flow rates is performed at −0.7 V vs. RHE. The result illustrates that the change in NH3 production rate and FE is not obvious (Fig. 6b), which proves that the diffusion of N2 does not affect the NRR performance significantly. The time-dependent current density curves at different potentials (Fig. 6c) demonstrate that the current density remains stable at these potentials, indicating that the CT-MX material has excellent chemical stability at −0.6 V to −0.8 V vs. RHE. The source of N2 is detected by the 1H NMR test in JNM-ECZ400S (Fig. 6d). CT-MX sample was tested with 14N2 as the feeding gas. The related 1H NMR spectrum of CT-MX (curve orange in Fig. 6d) shows the visible triplet coupling peaks, corresponding to that of 14NH4 + standard sample (curve black in Fig. 6d), which proves the existence of NH4 + product after NRR electrolysis. Afterwards, 14N2 was replaced with 15N2 (15N2 has a purity of over 99.9% atom). The related 1H NMR spectrum of CT-MX (curve red in Fig. 6d) exhibits the doublet coupling peaks characteristic of 15NH4 + standard sample (curve blue in Fig. 6d) after NRR test at the same potential. And no obvious characteristic signals of 14NH4 + are detected. These results of 1H NMR indicated that the generated NH3 all originates from the electrocatalytic N2 reduction reaction rather than the air or the sample itself. The double-layer capacitance method is used to test the electrochemical active area (ECSA), which further illustrates the improvement of hydrophobic modification on the NRR process. As shown in Fig. S11, the C dl of MXene is 9.6 mF cm−2, while that of CT-MX is 20.7 mF cm−2, the increase in electrochemical active area is beneficial for NRR. During the synthesis process, different concentrations of CTAB were added to obtain materials with different surface coverage of CTAB and NRR performance was tested. The results are shown in Fig. S12. As the addition content increases, the surface coverage of CTAB increases, which can effectively block the entry of H2O molecules, making the reaction more inclined towards NRR rather than HER, and the Faraday efficiency gradually increases; when the content of CTAB exceeds 6%, the FE gradually decreases. This is because the adsorption of CTAB molecules on the MXene surface through electrostatic interactions has a certain limit. Excessive CTAB molecules not only block the entry of H2O molecules, but also block the entry of N2 molecules, resulting in a decrease in the efficiency of NRR and a decrease in FE. Meanwhile, to prevent the workstation from affecting the experimental results, the NRR test subjected to the open circuit potential for 2 h is performed. The NRR test is also carried out for 2 h in a saturated Ar solution of −0.7 V vs. RHE. The solution after the above NRR experiment is tested by the UV-Vis spectrophotometer, which is shown in Fig. S13. Only a small amount of NH3 is generated within the allowable error range under two conditions. This also proves that the final NH3 gas is indeed derived from the NRR process of CT-MX. In addition to the excellent anti-oxidation ability of CT-MX mentioned above, 5 continuous NRR tests are tested after 6 months of storage under air conditions (Fig. S14), demonstrating that CT-MX still maintains superior NRR performance after long-term storage, which is a major advantage of hydrophobic modification. As shown in Fig. 2(a), the XRD pattern of CT-MX after 6 months of storage under air has not changed significantly compared to the previous CT-MX. Fig. S15 shows the layered structure of MXene placed in the air for 6 months appears partially closed, proving it was oxidized, while the structure of CT-MX does not change significantly after being placed in the air for 6 months. Fig. 2(a) and Fig. S15 confirm that the MXene treated by surface hydrophobization can effectively solve the shortcomings of poor hydration resistance and weak oxidation stability of MXene materials, which are easier to store in the air. Besides, the insertion of CTAB and FOTS molecules into the layers of Ti3C2 MXene can also cause an increase in the interlayer spacing [62–64]. 3.3 In situ FT-IR, DFT, and MD calculations The reaction process of NRR was further monitored at the molecular level by in situ FT-IR technique. Fig. 7 and Fig. S16 show the in situ FT-IR data of CT-MX and MXene, respectively. As observed, the signal at 1178 cm−1 is assigned to the N–N stretching band and its intensity is gradually increased with test time, which indicates the cleavage of the N≡N bond from N2 molecule [68,69]. Another three weak signals are ascribed to N–H stretching (3230 cm−1), H–N–H bending (1505 cm−1) and –NH2 wagging (1322 cm−1), respectively [65–67]. It implies that −N x H y species are generated due to the hydrogenation reaction of N species adsorbed on the catalyst’s surface. The final product of NH3 is further confirmed by detecting the symmetric and asymmetric deformation modes of δsNH4 + (1644 cm−1) and δasNH4 + (1482 cm−1) [68,69]. Additionally, it is noted that two strong signals near 3100 and 1600 cm−1 mainly originate from O–H stretching and H–O–H bending from adsorbed H2O molecules [70]. In situ FT-IR intermediate signals mainly correspond to water-related intermediates such as –OH, H–O–H, etc. After careful analysis, the signal intensity characteristic of H2O molecule on CT-MX (Fig. 7a) is much lower than that on MXene (Fig. 7b), indicating that the former is more hydrophobic due to the CTAB modification [71]. Generally, the hydrophobic feature could hinder the hydrogen evolution catalysis of catalyst material [66]. It is worth noting that the original structure of MXene is not changed due to surface hydrophobic modification, so the CT-MX catalyst has the same active site as MXene. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations are carried out on MXene to further explore the reaction path of the NRR process, and the diffusion of H2O and H2 on the catalyst surface with and without surfactants is calculated by Molecular Dynamics (MD) simulations to study the effect of surfactants on NRR performance. Fig. S17 shows stable adsorption models of NRR on partially oxidized MXene. The kinetic pathway of NRR is studied based on the calculated Gibbs free energy (ΔG) diagrams. Distal and alternative pathways are calculated (Fig. 8 a and b). Fig. S18 displays the adsorption geometries of other important intermediates on partially oxidized MXene along the distal pathway. It can be inferred from Fig. 8(b) that there are two pathways for the hydrogenation of *NNH, one is *NNH→*NNH2 and the other is *NNH→*NHNH. Obviously, the process of *NHNH to *NHNH2 in the alternative path is an energy-reducing path, ΔG = −1.33 eV, lower than the process of *NNH2 to *N in the distal path, ΔG = 2.75 eV. Besides, the potential-determining step (PDS) along the alternate pathway is 1.36 eV and the adsorption geometries of intermediates are displayed in Fig. 8(a). In summary, the alternative pathway is a more prone pathway compared with the distal pathway during the NRR process. MD simulations can visualize the role of hydrophobic modification in the NRR process. The N (nitrogen molecules)/N (water molecules) was set to 40/2000. The results (Fig. 8c–f) show the schematic diagram of MD simulations for the time-dependent changes of water and N2 molecules on the surface of MXene. There are a large number of active sites on the catalyst surface. N2 and H2O molecules will reach the corresponding active site on the catalyst surface for reduction reaction during the NRR process to generate NH3 and by-product H2, respectively. Although the reduction of N2 to NH3 is the main reaction due to the low reaction energy of H2, HER inevitably occurs during the reduction process, which is the reason for the low ammonia production rate. Hydrophobic modification is selected to solve this problem by inhibiting the entry of water molecules to suppress HER, thereby significantly improving NRR performance. For unmodified MXene (Fig. 8d), water and N2 molecules in the solution moved freely to the active sites on the MXene surface and participated in NRR. After modification by CTAB (Fig. 8f), water molecules in the solution are blocked due to the presence of a large number of CTAB molecules on the CT-MX surface, thereby reducing H ions to inhibit HER, while N2 can pass unblocked as before and reach the corresponding active site on the surface of MXene, which can effectively inhibit HER, thereby improving the ammonia production rate and FE. MD simulations prove that the surfactant plays an excellent role in preventing the diffusion of water molecules, thereby promoting the NRR process. More calculation details are available in the Supporting Information. In general, the excellent selective and high performance of CT-MX and FO-MX are proven with a high NH3 production rate and FE, mainly due to the following reasons: (1) Ti3C2 MXene material presents excellent conductivity, and surface hydrophobic modification cannot change its internal structure, which is beneficial for electron transfer during NRR process. (2) After hydrophobic modification, the surfactant molecules are squeezed into Ti3C2 MXene, which increases the specific surface area of the material and allows more N2 to participate in the NRR process, resulting in a faster and more complete reaction. (3) Surface hydrophobicity modification inhibits the entry of water molecules, reduces the concentration of hydrogen ions, and is less susceptible to activate proton H in the material, thus making the reaction more inclined towards NRR rather than HER. According to the comparison of current densities among the three samples in Fig. S19, surface modification does indeed lead to a decrease in electron transfer, but only a slight decrease. However, surface modification not only effectively increases hydrophobicity and suppresses HER. According to electrocatalytic active surface area (ECSA, Fig. S11) calculations, surface modification increases the electrochemically active area. Overall, surface modification is beneficial for the NRR process. 4 Conclusions We found that the NRR performance can be greatly improved by a more hydrophobic surface of MXene. The NH3 production rate and FE can be improved from 37.62 to 54.01 μg h−1 mg−1 cat., and 5.5% to 18.1% at −0.7 V. More importantly, after surface hydrophobic modification, the Ti3C2 MXene can be stored in room temperature air for a longer time, which solves the shortcomings of easy oxidation and poor hydration resistance of MXene. 15N isotopic labeling experiment confirms that nitrogen in produced ammonia originates from N2 in the electrolyte. In situ FT-IR, DFT and molecular dynamics calculations confirm that the surface hydrophobic MXene presents excellent NRR activity, mainly because the surfactant molecule does not change the original structure of MXene and retains the active site of NRR, but inhibits the entry of water molecules in the process, thus inhibiting competitive HER, making the catalyst more favorable to NRR rather than HER in the reaction process. These results open a new door for the rational design of more active electrocatalysts for various reactions. coredata.dc:description: Hydrophobic treatment of the catalyst surfaces can suppress the competitive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) during the nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR). In this work, the surface of Ti3C2Ti x MXene is modified by cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) and trimethoxy (3,3,4,4,5,5,6,6,7,7,8,8,8-tridecafluorooctyl) silane (FOTS) to increase the hydrophobicity of MXenes. The ammonia (NH3) production rate and faradaic efficiency (FE) are improved from 37.62 to 54.01 μg h−1 mg−1 cat. and 5.5% to 18.1% at −0.7 V vs. RHE, respectively after surface modification. 15N isotopic labeling experiment confirms that nitrogen in produced ammonia originates from N2 in the electrolyte. The excellent NRR activity of surface hydrophobic MXenes is mainly due to surfactant molecules, which inhibit the entry of water molecules and the competitive HER, which have been verified by in situ FT-IR, DFT and molecular dynamics calculations. This strategy provides an ingenious method to design more active NRR electrocatalysts.
